headline: Inside Politics
subHeadline: Auto Workers Union Wavers On Endorsing Biden; GOP Group Uses Barbie Meme To Hit Dems; Justice Dept To Take Legal Action Against Texas Over Floating Razor Wire Border Barrier; CNN: Dem Concerns Growing Over Cornel West Green Party Run; Legendary Singer Tony Bennett Dead At 96. Aired 12:30-1p ET

utterances.speaker: MELANIE ZANONA, CNN CAPITOL HILL REPORTER
utterances.sentences: -- again. And Donald Trump is also trying to capitalize on this rift that has emerged with Biden. Yes, he's pro-labor, pro-union, but he's also pro-environmentalist, and that has caused a rift between these two core constituencies. The push for electric vehicles is something that has ruled UAW and one of the things that they've criticized Biden over.So they have withheld their endorsement of Biden for now. I think part of that there is they're trying to get more of a commitment from Biden as they head into these critical labor negotiations, but it's certainly not a constituency that Democrats can take advantage, take for granted.

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: You're nodding your head.

utterances.speaker: TOLUSE OLORUNNIPA, WHITE HOUSE BUREAU CHIEF, THE WASHINGTON POST
utterances.sentences: The -- for sure. I think Biden realizes that if he's going to win Michigan and Wisconsin and Pennsylvania and a number of these other states, he's going to need to appeal directly to the union voters.Every time he speaks in front of a crowd, he talks about how he's the most pro-union president. He talks about how union workers are the best workers, and he's going to be doing that for the next several months for sure.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, Barbie.(MUSIC) (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Now, we would like to note the studio that produced Barbie is owned by Warner Brothers Discovery, which also is CNN's parent company.My panel is back. It's nice to see that these politicians can have a little fun, not just with the sports when that happens, the big Super Bowl or the World Series, but with a cultural moment, which is what this is.

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: Yes. And on Capitol Hill, I would just say, in terms of embracing the Barbie corps fashion, we have seen lawmakers, more and more female lawmakers expressing themselves. And I think for so long --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's interesting.

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: -- particularly in the political world, women are told or discouraged from showing themselves. You need to sort of downplay your femininity, and it's taught that it's almost a liability, not an asset, and that people will be distracted if you're wearing a certain color or hoop earrings or whatever it might be.But it has really resonated, not just on Capitol Hill, but all throughout the country, particularly with women who are now embracing this sort of Barbiecore phenomenon.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You've seen it?

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: Yes, I have seen it, and I've seen --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You see both?

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: I've seen both.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK. So you're a Barbenheimer.

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: I'm a Barbie.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I just want to point out that you are kind of -- with your tie, you're going Barbie and Ken.

utterances.speaker: JEFF ZELENY, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL AFFAIRS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: For sure. Why not?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I love it. I love it. So we have -- I have some props. I have some props. So you can pick if you want to do. Eye glasses or the Barbie glasses.

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: I need to do Barbie purse (ph).

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK. There you go. You definitely need a prop also. But in all seriousness, the fact that -- actually there's no all seriousness.

utterances.speaker: ZELENY
utterances.sentences: But I think the Governor Whitmer thing is actually very interesting --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's clever.

utterances.speaker: ZELENY
utterances.sentences: -- that she's embracing this because a few years ago --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: ZELENY
utterances.sentences: -- you know, to be a strong female governor, you wouldn't necessarily want to be associated with this.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's exactly right.

utterances.speaker: ZELENY
utterances.sentences: And I was thinking back to 2016 during that presidential campaign when there was a skit on SNL and there was President Barbie who was kind of made to look like Hillary Clinton, and the young girls didn't want to play with it. And they said, oh, there can be a female president. They weren't interested.And that was sort of something at the time. The Clinton campaign kind of recoiled at. Fast forward eight years later, so much has --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's such a good point.

utterances.speaker: ZELENY
utterances.sentences: -- in politics, and I think the Governor Whitmer people are obviously leading the charge on this and not only embracing it, they're doing it. BASHPete Buttigieg --

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: That's Pete Buttigieg, yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And he's just Ken and that is --

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: Ouch.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's the president.

utterances.speaker: OLORUNNIPA
utterances.sentences: Nothing is above politics of this day and age. And you're not surprised at all to see this sort of become a partisan battle. I do think it has been interesting to see a number of male politicians who, when asked about sort of which movie they wanted to watch, said they wanted to be --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: They chose Barbie.

utterances.speaker: OLORUNNIPA
utterances.sentences: -- Barbie even though, you know, Oppenheimer is sort of the serious, you know, movie that involves --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: OLORUNNIPA
utterances.sentences: -- Congress and has congressional hearings involved in everything. So I think everyone's getting swept up.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK, well, this is something that you can have in the spirit of that, the Barbie hat. There you go. It's all yours.

utterances.speaker: ZANONA
utterances.sentences: Joining the crew.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: A new escalation in the tensions between the Biden administration and Texas Republican governor. CNN has learned the Justice Department is planning to take legal action against the state over the placement of floating razor wire barriers in the river along its border with Mexico.CNN's Priscilla Alvarez is breaking the story. What are you learning? [12:45:08] PRISCILLA ALVAREZ, CNN WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT: This is a significant escalation and development, Dana, in a feud between Texas Governor Greg Abbot and President Biden over a delicate political issue being immigration. So the DOJ telling Abbot on Thursday that they plan to file legal action against the floating barriers that were put up by Abbott in the Rio Grande, saying, quote, "The state of Texas actions violate federal law, raise humanitarian concerns, present serious risks to public safety and the environment, and may interfere with the federal government's ability to carry out its official duties" Dana, I've been talking to officials for months who said there was ongoing discussions between the Department of Homeland Security and the Justice Department as to what to do against the Texas governor and his border operation. They are now moving forward, potentially with this legal action. But we should note, this is unrelated to the ongoing assessment about mistreatment of migrants. Dana?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Priscilla, thank you so much for that reporting. Appreciate it.And President Biden is prepared to take on a Republican on the ballot next fall, but is he ready for a challenge from the left? Cornel West, a semi-celebrity among progressives, is running on the Green Party ticket next November. That's the same party that Democrats blame for spoiling the 2016 election. And CNN's Isaac Dovere and Eva McKend are here with new reporting on growing concerns among some Democrats who see a progressive Green Party bid sneaking up on President Biden. And they're here to discuss now. First of all, this quote from David Axelrod, who's our colleague who helped get Barack Obama elected, "This is going to sneak up on people". And he said, "I don't know why alarm bells aren't going off now. They should be at a steady drumbeat from now until the election". I'm sure they were thrilled to see that in the White House.

utterances.speaker: ISAAC DOVERE, CNN SENIOR REPORTER
utterances.sentences: As they often are when David Axelrod makes a comment like that. But with the mixed metaphor that he used there, though, is getting it where a lot of Democrats are thinking about this. And within the Biden campaign itself, there's not concern so far about this, but the Green Party has a ballot line in a number of states already.I think it's 16 states already. In 2016, they were in 44 states. So when you think about the attention that's been going to this no labels --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: -- possibility and how that could spoil the election, they are still getting on the ballot, whereas the Green Party is much easier to get there and would be there with a candidate who is well known among progressives, has celebrity and connection to a lot of black voters. And that is what is generating this concern.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Such an important point. And you have a quote in your story from the Michigan Democratic Party chair saying, "I don't think Cornel West or the Green Party is something we need to worry about, but it's absolutely something we need to keep an eye on". But I'm sure that that party chair knows the history of that state and also Pennsylvania and Wisconsin back in 2016.You just have to look at what happened. The Green Party, look at Jill. Stein was on the Green Party ballot then. Look at the vote she got and look at Donald Trump's margin.

utterances.speaker: EVA MCKEND, CNN NATIONAL POLITICS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Now, Democrats can't afford to cede any of their coalition. So I think that some are recognizing that they would be remiss to ignore the threat of Cornel West. Something that struck me about our conversation with him is the attacks are so pointed.And I asked him, did you vote for President Biden in 2020? Why are you so disappointed by him? And then when you kicked the tires a bit, even though he was part of this antifascist coalition of Bernie Sanders supporters that spoke well of Biden, he got in the voting booth and didn't actually vote for Joe Biden. And the way that he described that evolution on that issue, I think was in an authentic way that other progressives will be able to connect with that message. So I think that should be of concern to Democrats.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: Yes. The argument that Jill Stein makes for what happened in 2016 and West echoes and should be said Stein is working on West campaign now --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: -- is that those voters wouldn't have turned out at all. They weren't Hillary Clinton voters who left.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: That is not something that is going to put people in a very comfortable place going into what many of us expect to be a tight election.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Such important reporting. You can read the full story on CNN.com. Thanks for sharing it with us.

utterances.speaker: DOVERE
utterances.sentences: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's an end of an era in the music world.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: TONY BENNETT, LEGENDARY SINGER
utterances.sentences: I left my heart)(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: When you're on the campaign trail with Al Gore. "Tony Bennett's on stage right now, pompadour frizzy and wild, suit shiny and gray, with a red hanky in his pocket. He doesn't really fit in with the country and western theme of the night, but he's a star, so whatever. The best is yet to come and babe, won't it be fine, he croons." Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The hoe down before the showdown. I do remember that. I guess I saw him in concert briefly. There were a lot of stars that came out for Al Gore in the year 2000. And he's -- obviously, Tony Bennett had a proud record as a liberal and a Democrat, but I don't remember --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- that part of him. I just think about his music and --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- what a beautiful singer he was. And he said I read in one of his obits today he wanted to be known for being a nice guy. And I think his legacy is pretty secure. He was known for being a lovely, lovely man.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And we were talking, I mean, 96 years. That's a --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: That's a great run.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's a great run.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: We should all be so lucky. He had a great, great life. I mean, when you think about everything he fought in World War II, huge star, et cetera.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK, so let's talk about this. I somehow have ended up with two books here, which I'm happy to take.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, one you actually read --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: -- and the other one is the cleaner version.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thank you. OK. Yes. One is all marked up, "All The Demons Are Here". There are so many things I wanted to talk to you about, but let's just focus on the characters. The main characters are siblings, Ike and Lucy. Lucy's struggling to get recognition.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: The 22-year-old journalist, aspiring journalist in Washington, D.C. trying to make it in a man's world.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: In the 1970s.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: 1977, but I really liked her parents, especially her father, who was a fictitious Republican senator in the post-Nixon era. He was somebody who you made helped push out Nixon along with Howard.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. He was on the House Judiciary Committee and along with Larry Hogan Sr. voted to -- voted for the articles of impeachment.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. So I love this is true historical fiction. There's a section where Lucy, the daughter, is having lunch with her parents in the Senate dining room, and she says, "Dad says there's a House caucus of Nixon Nuts. They want to bring Nixon back. They're saying the whole Watergate thing was a liberal plot".And then her mother says, "Your father's party is about to descend into oophagy.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oophagy.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: By the way, she was a zoologist.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: So Margaret's a zoologist.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Oophagy is when sharks in embryo eat the other eggs of their shark. BASH

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, my characters are generally much smarter than me, and like -- but I just thought of, like, Margaret is left of center, and so she looks at her husband's party skeptically, but also just the fact that there was going to be all this jockeying for the 1980 presidential nomination. And she talks about animals a lot.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But I do like this because there's so many points in this book where you 'resaying you think, oh, wow, that's a parallel to today.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But this is one of them, because he's talking about being kind of an old school Republican, and he's seeing his party change before his eyes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, the party is becoming more and more conservative. The party gets rid of the ERA and the civil rights platforms, in the Republican National Committee platform document from 76 to 80. Ronald Reagan becomes ascendant and it becomes a more conservative party.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: There's another storyline about Vietnam vets living in the woods, some of whom are clearly sick because they were exposed to Agent Orange.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Although the government at that point is not acknowledging it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And not -- and refusing to pay for any treatments for these Vietnam veterans.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What's the genesis of this?

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, it's interesting you ask. So I wrote a book about Afghanistan, a real -- a non-fiction book about Afghanistan, about Combat Outpost Keating. And the lieutenant governor of Delaware was moved by the stories, not by me, but by the actual true life stories. He invited me and a bunch of the guys who actually served at Combat Outpost Keating to an event in Delaware.And I heard from Delaware public officials about Afghanistan and Iraq veterans living in the woods. They had gone off the grid. They couldn't deal with contemporary society. I tried to report on it. I could never find them. But their legacy lives on in this fictitious band of camping Vietnam veterans.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: OK, well, this has everything. It's got Evel Knievel.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's got --

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Elvis? BASH

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Son of Sam?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: All of it. It's really good. I have to say I just couldn't get off the couch one weekend day. I read the entire thing.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Really in one setting?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. And I want to say that this looks like a thriller, and it is a thriller, but there's a lot of -- there's some chiclet in here.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Well, it's written in -- as you know, it's written in first person, alternating chapters. Ike writes a chapter. Lucy writes a chapter.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: And it's very important for me to have strong female protagonists.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, there were a couple of them.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Thank you. Thanks for sharing.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Thanks, Dana.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Join me this Sunday on State of the Union. That's -- it's nice that you're here, my co-anchor.

utterances.speaker: TAPPER
utterances.sentences: Yes. Keep going.
